how-gravity-is-created-through-electroma.title: How Gravity is created through Electromagnetism; Understanding Einstein's stress-energy tensor
how-gravity-is-created-through-electroma.description:
This slightly feels sci-fi, however the claims are backed up theoretically, it's just a fun quirk of general relativity that is very interesting to observe. None of this is practically possible just yet, but maybe in the near future though ;)Throughout the blog, as is common I've used Einstein Notation, would recommend reading it up quickly here incase you care about the math here - which there is a bit of.You must've heard of Einstein's General Relativity, right? From all those pop-sci physics videos you've been stacking up? There you would've learnt about relativity in an analogy with a mass on a fabric, bending the fabric around it as such - and then you would've expanded that thinking into thinking that the mass bends space-time around it, a 3-D Fabric being bent in a 4-dimensional way.
Further, if you have ever pursued an undergraduate degree in physics, you must've learnt about general relativity - and the following equation, which describes the curvature of space-time. G is Newton's Gravitational Constant that you may have previously learnt about in high-school physics. (pronounced 'kah-pah') is known as the Einstein's Gravitational constant. We won't be writing that, doesn't make much of a difference anyways.For those who are not aware, here, the terms describe the curvature and shape of spacetime, very complicated and interesting stuff, but let's not go into much detail over there just yet. You may also notice a this is also pretty interesting, this defines the curvature due to empty-space, here, defines the metric tensor, which can be thought of (for simplicity, and at-least in euclidean space) as a "unit" of spacetime, as it defines how distance and "time" are measured. (remember, spacetime is one thing now, time is just another co-ordinate of space!)Here, the terms tell us how much 'distance' is gained for each co-ordinate, while the terms tell us how the co-ordinates 'mix together' and interact, think if you have a vector of length , and it's x-component is units and y-component units. If you keep it's length the same, but move the vector to a new point where it's x-component is units, clearly, the y-component would increase to units. Quite the similar thing over here! is set according to the space we're in, for what is known as the Minkowski Space, which is a flat & 4D (3 Space + 1 Time dimensions) we get (Actually, all the signs can be reversed as well, (+, -, -, -) works too), this will be useful later, keep this in mind. This is in the covariant form, to convert between covariant and contravariant (i.e. you can use find the matrix inverse because of the relationship for the minkowski space though, they are equal as the tensor is it's own inverse.For some vector , the metric tensor helps us convert between covariant/vector () and contravariant () forms, by and The symbol, defines the cosmological constant, fancy term, but all that it really says is that even empty-space has some energy to it. Actually, the term represents the energy-density of empty space, and is related to expansion/contraction of the universe. If you want to learn more about these concepts, I'd suggest checking out the Libretext Physics pages on these, now, let's get to the juicy partLet's look at the last term that's left now. Here represents the stress-energy tensor. I'd argue this is one of the most important aspects of general relativity, as it is what defines how objects with energy or momentum can distort spacetime. Yes! It isn't mass that bends spacetime, but rather energy and momentum! You can check how the stress-energy tensor arises in Appendix 1Let's also write the stress-energy tensor in a matrix form, to better understand what it's made up of,Here, defines the multiplying this by gives us the Energy Density (See: ) Actually, is just Energy Density expressed in mass units, this will be important in just a bit! defines the of the momentum or amount of k-th component of momentum per unit volume. (How much is present) defines the or the or how much k-th momentum flows per unit area per unit time. (How much is moving)The other elements represent the flux-density of the k-th component across a surface perpendicular to the k-th axis, for this gives us the , while for it represents or .Which fits into our original equation, This works for rest-mass, but as we just discussed, it's not just rest-mass which affects spacetime, but actually the energy and momentum. So calling the relativistic mass may be a bit confusing, since what we're actually, physically measuring is the Energy Density, for the rest of the blog, I'll be calling it the Energy Density. (This does mean that, technically speaking an electromagnetic field can also have mass, which is also a very interesting point whose consequences I may touch upon in a later 'appendix' perhaps).So, we can use our field equation for anything that affects energy and momentum, something like the Electromagnetism perhaps! Well, is the general stress-energy tensor which arises from anything that affects momentum & energy, is the Electromagnetic Stress Energy tensor, which arises due to electromagnetic fields. It is written as Cool. Fancy equation. Now what the hell does that mean?Side-note, you can check the derivation for Electromagnetism Stress-Energy tensor from Appendix 2Well, let's analyse the first term: represents the electromagnetic field tensor in covariant form, which is written as, I would recommend you to learn more about the electromagnetic field tensor from Chapter 12 of Introduction To Electrodynamics by GriffithsRemember Einstein Notation, from which we know for clarity, we can expand this as follows, for some and , Now looking at the second term, So, generally we get the equation for our tensor to be, Great! With this we can find the electromagnetic stress-energy for any spacetime. However, we must first specify the type of spacetime we're using. For the sake of this blog, I'll just go with Minkowski spacetime, this is a flat 4-Dimensional spacetime, with 3 space dimensions and 1 time dimension, for which we get the metric tensor in the form (+, -, -, -) or (-, + + +), let's work with the latter. (this is what it looks like btw)
According to convention we'll write for Minkowski Spacetime and as mentioned earlier we know (read annotation in metric tensor).This will specify our general space equation for the stress-energy to Cool, let's start evaluating our , I'll show the first element as a sample calculation, but the rest is left as an exercise to the reader.We can write the first term as, Taking a look again at our Electromagnetic Field Tensor, and our Minkowski Metric Tensor, We can see that and , so we can write Summing over we get, Similarly, we can find for the second term, , now, Alright, so we can divide this sum into three parts, namely, the which is just , the time-space components, and , so, For the space-space components, we get (Tensor for reference) Let's look at the time-space components, here because the field tensor is asymmetric we get that, and which gives us, Therefore the sum of the two time-space parts will be, We can write this as, Again, since we're using the signs (-, +, +, +) here, we get that, , and any other (note: here, we aren't working with the time-time component, where ) so we get that, which gives us, We can see from the tensor the summation of terms is just so, Dividing by we get, Now, we can look at the space-space component, we have, where as discussed previously, therefore,Now, we sum over, , and divide by (why divide by two? well, since summing over would count every element twice.), so we get, Evaluating, Therefore we get that, So, adding all the three parts we get, (also, since we aren't working with SI units right now anyways, I'll just set & for convenience, I'll bring SI units back in when we need them for proper calculations for the possible applications) Now going all the way back to our stress-energy tensor equation, we have the equation This is known as the energy density.Therefore, we get our stress-energy tensor as, For the sake of keeping this blog short, I'll let you work-out the rest of the variables (trust me, it won't take that long), for now, just take this as a blackbox truth that the Electromagnetic Stress Energy tensor(SI units) in the Minkowski spacetime looks like this,Here, are the poynting vectors and is the maxwell stress tensor, and is defined as, This electromagnetic stress-energy tensor is what determines how electromagnetic fields affect the geometry of spacetime. This means a sufficiently strong electromagnetic field is capable of producing gravity. I wanted to prioritise the core theory in this blog, but of course, the interesting part obviously lies in the consequences and applications, now, in-reality the gravitational effect of electromagnetic fields is extremely weak and not really useful for any major applications just yet (but if you do have any cool ideas, please send me a mail :)), but this doesn't mean we can't explore some interesting theoretical applications of course.The first and most interesting case that would probably pop up in your mind, is that light has electromagnetic fields, does that mean light has a gravitational effect too? And the answer is *Yes!*Now, Photons aren't fermions, so they aren't subject to the Pauli Exclusion Principle. They are bosons, they can stack together. Which means we can sort of, play around, and create a blackhole with a bunch of high-energy photons. This is known as the kugelblitz.
Another cool application are spinning superconductors and gravitomagnetic fields, gravitomagnetic fields are, as the name suggests, the magnetic equivalent of gravity or . magnetic field : electric field :: gravitomagnetic field : gravitational field, in the common fabric relativity analogy this is like the mass spinning and twisting the fabric.

Interestingly, since superconductors would have an electromagnetic field, when they're spun around quite fast, they may produce a large gravitomagnetic effect. I couldn't find many experimental studies, except one controversial one that claimed to have seen effects of up to times Earths Gravity, which is MASSIVE, though, this study has had trouble being replicated, and the actual gravitomagnetic effect is seen to be much smaller, and has only truly been observed at planetary scales or more by satellites such as in the Gravity Probe B experiment.There are quite a few interesting use-cases of EM gravity, though it seems largely unviable for near-term applications since it is so weak. That doesn't mean we can't explore some cool, albeit theoretical, concepts, or try to think of possible applications - since that's always fun to do. :)That's kind of it for the blog, I've put a few more derivations in the appendix you may wanna check out (I'll put that in maybe a day or two after this blog is up though.)See ya!

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
